titleStmt.title: J. S. Smith, Jr. et al. to Beriah Magoffin
CWG9428

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p:
To his excelancy, Beriah McGoffin the govenor of the Commonwealth of Ky. Your petitioner Munroe Lane would respectfully state to your excelancy, that at the March term of the Nelson Circuit Court 1861, he was found guilty of a misdemeanor by the virdict of a jury of said County, and fined the sum of $200, & six months imprisonment in the County Jail and that inconsequence of said finding and the verdict judgment of the court thereon he is now imprisoned in the County jail of the County of Nelson. He states that he is very poor and has neither friends and nor relitives, nor has he any means out of which he can pay said fine or any part thereof -- He states further that not having any means to satisfy said fine he is advised that he will have to lay in jail and discharge the same by imprisonment at the rate of two dollars per day, which will lengthen his imprisonment to a period of more than nine months and ^which^ will greatly impair if not entirely destory the health of your petitioner. He states further, that if he was released from his imprisonment, that he would by honest industry endeavour to earn the means and pay the fine imposed upon him. The premises considered
your petitioner (and those whose names are attached) most respectfully solicits the pardon of your excelancy and that your petitioner he thereby released form so much of said penalty as relates to his imprisonment

J. s. Smith Jr
Joseph Queen
Jno. Morton
A E Mattingly

As Mr. Lane is in confinement for the fine of $200 -- the pardon should endorse a release of that also as he is wholy unable to pay it and the he will well be
